I retort, the bug itself cant lie in PGP, PGP just unencrypt things you passed through it and return it, that's all it is or should ever be responsible for in this context
I suspect the fault lies in the mail client
so a better advice is to DISABLE PGP mail and use PGP command line, there's no way you can go wrong with that

1527003512_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGG.body:
>So how does one now call up the uncensored version of this site on this censorship-resistant network, or even fork the whole site?
apparently the owner censored it themself(according to the website which we cant confirm), we cant really stop owners from censoring their own sites
just like how giving me the rights to edit this post, also gives me the right to edit, or delete this post thus censoring it
if anyone gain access to the owner's PC/site private key, they can also do that, which again is out of our control if you slipped up

> [vychlop](#comment_1_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): I get that the owner has control over what appears under a certain identifier. [...]

you cant, that's only possible if someone archived or saved an older version as of now
tho i dont really get why the owner in this case want to remove said sites, since there no way of things begin taken down, unless you leaked something confidential by accident i dont think there should be an issue
infact, if your site will be more secure/reliable by having more peers

> [vychlop](#comment_2_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): Wow. That's sounds like a giant oversight. Enables the most obvious methods people always have censored content with and it also makes it opaque that censorship is happening when it is happening. [...]

you can "fork" by saving the current site as a zip, afaik in the bleeding edge built rn

while i agree but again not a lot of people like it that their site will have snapshots of it
and there's also a thing about you can only snapshot something you know of(we cant expect owner to allow the snapshot in worst circumstances)
also even daily snapshots could means wasting shit ton of data just for one possible chance of an act of censoring

tho maybe something about githistory, where peers will keep something like a gitlog of each changes, to prevent repeat saving unnecessary data, and easy reverts shall anything happen, but this relies on peers to be bothered to save the history

to start we can make a plugin that will enable snapshot for sites, like logging change every 7days to 1hr to every change detected(depending on risk factor and disk space to spare), when a peer needs it, peer can revert to last know good state
it cant be tampered since signatures are saved and verified

for second step, we can develop a protocol to share/seed snapshots just like how we are already seeding sites
say i do 1 snapshot every day, if i need a finer timings, i can ask for it between all knows peers, and slowly downloading the git history piece from them, once completed i can revert to it

then we can also have customizable schedules, say all normal sites = snapshot once every 4-7 days(varied random to allow each peers by chance to have a different dated copy)by default but still allowing specific highrisk pages to be monitored for all detected changes etc

but again this all assume people care enough to spend more disk space to store history, but i agree this is an interesting case and we definitely have more work to do(random note you cant archive tor because source code is behind a server, you can archive everything with zeronet because all code and data client sided)

what great of this community is we can discover flaws and discuss fixes together

> [vychlop](#comment_3_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): I honestly thought that would happen automatically. People who just visit store up to the site storage limit, and people who mirror store the whole thing. I didn't think you can affect the mirrored copies.
> [vychlop](#comment_3_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): Yea, and I personally think that should be a feature.
tbh this network is kinda new so it can help with improvements and challenges to be thrown at it
the backups wont be affected in theory as it's set to not copy the latest changes

> [vychlop](#comment_3_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): Oh, I wasn't even aware I was talking to a dev before
not really a python dev but i like to speak as if what i can, to theorize possible fixes

also maybe someone can suggest a better ideas for ways to prevent censorship/sizing by owner

if it's implemented even if a site is somehow sized like it always happen in tor, anyone can fetch the latest know good copy and spin up a new site, since the backup have all the new site needs, previous data, source code, and all the things

> [krixano](#comment_449_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): We can clone and fork zites. It's just not automatic. You have to do it manually. And some zite owners allow the clone button, which you can find by clicking the 3 dots next to the zite name in ZeroHello.

no, that cloning does not store userdata, the idea of the backup is to stand against censorship by owner,
say for example, owner starts to mass delete things on example zerotalk, we can REVERT to last known GOOD STATE in history of zerotalk, and FORK it by cloning EVERYTHING, including userdata to another site which we CONTROL, to restore user freedom
what's empowering in this example is, anyone can do it, if a group of community dont like that, they can fork off into their own community
and yes i agree optional files might be a problem

> [blazar](#comment_24_1P1baCe1LLjror4CZjChWFy7D7cVWyPL83): If you want to access an older version of a zite you have to make a lot of backups. When someone dont do some work for you it is not censorship.

There's a difference, here we keep a LOG CHANGES, for example data deleted, data added, data edited, site html edited etc,
since now we have a log of changes, we can easily REVERT to when the log of changes is made,
using cronjob kinda works but like you said it create tons of unnecessary data, we dont need to know if a file was there untouched for years, we only care when it's touched
and i agree, user shouldnt be FORCED to make backup/log of history, for whatever or no reason, say lack of disk space, just like how uploading/seeding is done by merit not by force or economical incentive

> [blazar](#comment_25_1P1baCe1LLjror4CZjChWFy7D7cVWyPL83): The greatest idea keeping ZeroNet alive is transferring censorship rights from corporations and governments to every user.

then what's bad about the collective users also have a say in reverting owners change, isnt that more power to user?
Yes you will never get control of the owner's zite, but you have control to fork off owner site into a zite you have control, and pulling people who are against whatever owner's action together,
say a minority group getting harassed/banned by OWNERS of twitter wrongly, wouldnt the ability to fork everything including user data to another site of your own with 0 technical and coding skills, while rallying people who are banned to join that site?

> [krixano](#comment_450_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): I'm not sure what you are agreeing to about optional files
ahh there's no git history yet because we are here to implement it, what i say is problematic is cant really make a git history of something you dont know(like you can only have a git history of optional files you STORED)

for future reference, when i say "backup" i meant it in a git manner, where only changes are store, and can be reverted(dont really know what others means when they use "clone" with(like backup then) or without userdata)
and when i say "fork" i meant it as in restore to a backup state by undoing what changes that are logged/stored

> [krixano](#comment_452_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): This isn't quite true. Changes to zites do not propogate to forks/clones of those zites unless the owner manually clicks "update" to update the code from the zite they cloned from. Data is not copied over to other zite when using the ZeroNet clone feature. But you can still download the zites as zips periodically, which includes user data. The changes don't propogate to downloaded zips - that doesn't make any sense.

that's why we need another "clone" feature that logs changes and allow you to revert owner change + rehost
since data is not copied over using the current "clone" feature, tho i want to assume this is the same for the zip one

> [krixano](#comment_453_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): The zip download downloads all user data I'm pretty sure. So that should work. If not, then you can literally just have a program copy all of the files yourself. It's all manual right now, so a feature like patches or dvcs commits, etc., or even one to do automatic backups, would be good, perhaps.

something like a crontab that do `git add .&&git commit -am "$date"` in each zite every hour
not as streamlined but kinda workableish, but ideally a plugin will do it seamlessly that anyone without any technical knowledge can restore or create a zite from a set time period

1524935803_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3U.body:
>So how do you create a website that stays online and always reachable while still being decentralized? 

My personal answer is to share it with everyone, people who liked it will seed it for you, and your site is decentralized within your community

>leave their zeronet server constantly running on their home computer [...] relying on the person's home computer to host the site the majority of the time

not really true, you are relying on your peers/community that at any given moment there should be at least 1 peer existing thus the website will always be online; the more peers you have lower chance your site will go offline at any given timeframe, you are not exactly hoping for one peer who are always online(that's dangerous), but enough peer that any peer within the swarm can freely go off without taking the site along with it

personally i dont see anything wrong with a blocklist of any sort even automated, so long as user is AWARE and OPTED-IN
like say on first install user will be prompted with a SUGGESTION to subscribe to a recommended community blocklist(but what to block is beyond me), users still have a right to reject/accept and if they visited a blocklisted site they can whitelist it anyways if they wish
as long as it's not forced/hardcoded i dont see a problem in it
say if i visited a blocked site i just get a warning of why it's blocked, and i can move away or just whitelist it(temp or permanent)
say if a list has updated i have an OPTION to stay as current or update to new one while begin able to view pardons/bans added and reasoning of it(or i can enable auto update which is where it's dangerous)
it dosent hurt the freedom of zeronet if user visited the site they will still delete it anyways if they dont like to be seeding said contents so a blocklist is just made to help user to avoid said content in the first place

to avoid giving attention we could just block by hash() of site address but i dont think this is a good call as we are suppose to be open rather then be closed and hidden

we also have the problem of what to block?, say we passed all this hurdles and have a system in place, now what do we block??
personally i suggest we can have multiple blocklist like list of categories that is community moderated, people who dislike/dont want to view said type of content can subscribe, other who dont care, wont care
regarding antibot we COULD use POW system so each vote is backed by POW of some sort 

the problem with deleting site/not seeding a site is a problem arises due to how zeronet works one can really argue the ability to delete a site is an act of censorship and that zeronet shouldnt even allow it to happen(block site deletes)
it's a balance between power to user or to the sites

1523888661_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5.body:
> [glightstar](#comment_74_14K7EydgyeP84L1NKaAHBZTPQCev8BbqCy): The data won't get deleted when it's stored in localstorage, though of course, browsers aiming at anonymity or browsers that delete site's data, aren't included in that.. [...]

wouldnt that meant it gets shared to the network? i dont know why but i have an irrational fear of sharing that kind of data despite i know how it will be secured

also my initial plans was to make the seeds always persist on the device regardless of current user, maybe i can add an userdata.json and ignore it in the contents.json and we would just read and write off it instead of localstorage which is not shared with all users

> [glightstar](#comment_75_14K7EydgyeP84L1NKaAHBZTPQCev8BbqCy): Yeah, I mean that's what I said xDYou should definitely use the filesystem-API to read and write to a file, but it's pretty much your decision, on which of the two encryption methods you want to use (or you use a completely different one) and if you want that users can see their masterseeds everywhere for comfort, which, indeed, requires that other users are able to seed the file (so definitely encrypt in this case!!)

thanks i guess this is a good concept but have a ton of rough edges, maybe i will sand it all over in the future or someone will be happy to make it into something grander

1524765490_1D2E7WbvtaBxyunA2P3M1rFzsWBaZ.body:
Lets make a CNC structure based off how zeronet would function!
We could effectively hide who actually control the botnet, or its just another victim propagating commands throughout the network
and ideally it would be impossible to be shut down(unless the controller's keys get destroyed or self destruct command initiated via a compromised key if it's implemented)
problem arise when you want to send something back to the botmaster, essentially it's kinda a one way channel which is not very ideal for certain use cases

> [marcusbrix](#comment_3_1D2E7WbvtaBxyunA2P3M1rFzsWBaZhDUCW): That sounds like a really cool idea. Does ZeroNet have an API? But another problem, we would have to add the zeronet files to the payload, if it were to be done :(That would make deployment more difficult as the file would take up more space and use more resources running. [...]

Idea is to built another system up from ground but only possesses the necessary parts(bulky malware makes easy spotting) with barebone(we are suppose to just use mirror how zeronet works without using it)

For sake of example, say we managed to embed zeronet into your malware and
uses different ports etc so if by odds the user also have zeronet it wouldnt clash with it,
now we just need to call 127.0.0.1:ourport/(CNC's address)/ (we will open it on a hidden web browser because javascript is needed), but it will probably only be needed for the first time so zeronet knows we need it to seed that site,
now the malware can access zeronet'sroot/data/(cnc address)/commands.json or whatever it needed
all that left is for the botmaster to edit the site's commands.json and sign+publish it

But lets step back and think what this can be used for, all i can think of is just to use it for something like ddosing or flooding where a respond is not necessarily needed
You cant even do anything like the ransomware or just extract any data from infected host without doing something crazy(which only works if you alter the protocol grately) like each malware makes it's own site and propagate all malware peers to host it, the site itself will have the response, assuming the botmaster will be in the peer, they will automatically get the response that way without exposing themself since they could just be seen as just another infected machine doing what it was commanded to do(you could encrypt the response with owner's public key doe which means the response itself is actually secret)

**TLDR**: ideally you dont have to use zeronet but just use their concept, also doing it using zeronet which will only yield a one way connection is complicated, and the possibilities of altering the protocol and making it a two way connection thus making it more useful

> [marcusbrix](#comment_4_1D2E7WbvtaBxyunA2P3M1rFzsWBaZhDUCW): Well, it's an interesting idea, but pretty much just an idea for me as this is waayyyy above my level. It would be cool if it someone created it, though.

same here, i just like to think of all the cools way things could be done
maybe minus the someone created it part thought(or maybe not)
